text: Pours a nice amber with tan head. Aroma of dark fruits, oak, red wine, and rye spice.

Wow. Quite a creation by Deschutes. Manages to achieve the best aspects of a Belgian quad, while providing a taste and mouthfeel similar to an English Barleywine. Sweet, smooth, rich - its all there.

650 ml bottle. Pours a dark mahogany with moderate head. Aromas of candi sugar, sweet malts and tobacco. Flavors of candi sugar, oak, orange peel, and dry sweet malts. Definite ABV but still super stuff.

Bomber, a couple years old. Nose is raisins, chocolate, vanilla. Dark brown with orange tints, almost flavor. Tart fruit flavor, like a pomigranite, a bit oxidized, with nice tart notes. A bit thin but a very good American quad.

Bomber. Aged a couple of years. Rich deep dark fruit, dark sugar, and light tart berries. Reddish/brown color. Rich fruity flavors, tart prunes and berries. Thins out a touch in the finish. Very pleasant and tasty. Unfortunately, the flavors float away too quickly. Maybe should have been drunk a little earlier. Still, a top-notch quad.

650ml bottle @ home. 2015 Vintage
Pours a semi-opaque dirty rusty brown colour with an off-white head. Nose is brown sugar, Belgian yeasts, and dark fruits. Having sampled this before from a keg I recall it being very sweet. Having aged this bottle some taking in the new year, I find the sweetness has mellowed. Flavour has a lot going on in a good way. Toffee and brown sugar is present but not overbearing. Perhaps my palate is biased from the stoic, but once again I get the flavours of dark cherries, christmas cake mixed with some mild boozyness. Overall Im really enjoying this, more so than the stoic.

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2017 Poured from a bomber bottle into a short glass to drink. The beer had a cloudy and dark amber-copper color with a dark brown hue and a small foamy and creamy tan head with shorter retention and minimal cling and lacing. Its aroma featured strong notes of fruit malt, spices, floral hops, and a scent of brandy and malt liquor. The taste was somewhat sweet and fruity with a sour malt and floral effect. The beer was fairly thick in the mouth with average carbonation, and a noticeable presence of alcohol.  Big thanks to Eric for the special present!
Deep amber-copper color with slight white head. Light cherry and wood notes on the aroma. Fairly sweet light cherry cola and wine notes as well as some wood...light warming finish.

"Best after 4/22/15", enjoyed 11/27/15. Shared bomber in snifters. Dark auburn with small head that quickly faded. Smooth, almost creamy, mouthfeel. I taste the influence of the Belgian yeast, raisan/port/fig fruitiness (pomegranate molasses), as well as the wine and whiskey barrels. But none of those dominate. Instead they blend nicely together.  You know you are drinking a 12%ABV, but this beer doesnt make it a challenge.

Wax covered 650 ml bottle. Best after date of: 4/22/15. Color shows me a deep Crimson ruby color in a snifter. Decent amount of bubbly lace around the glass. aroma is candy sugar, toffee, caramelized sugar and plenty of Belgian yeast. 
It shows a subtle fruit like hint but I never would have guessed pomegranate. Lots of pitted fruits raisin, dates, figs. The whiskey is pretty light, as is the wine influence. Even after this much time, the alcohol is still VERY obvious. A bit much in the booze category. I thought now would be a good time to open it. Perhaps it could use just a bit more time? Hard to say.

Pours a semi translucent auburn. Creamy beige head. Outstanding carb bubble action. Smells of rum soaked marachino cherries and oak, with a brown sugared raisins to boot. Tastes of prune juice, cranberries, apple pie, with a sweet and dry port style finish. On the palate it thin, creamy, with moderate carbonation. Much better than I remember when I had it fresh. Its like a tropical fruit juice that has been fermented.

Pours pours deep brown/bronze with a small off white head. The aroma has rich caramel, Abbey yeast, oak, port and vanilla. It has a fairly full body with mild carbonation. The taste has figs, dates, milk caramel, vanilla, light spice and some alcohol. Pretty tasty.
Bottle. 2015 vintage. Pours ruby golden, white head. Aroma is bourbon, toffee, vanilla, fig, pomegranate. Really nice. Flavor is bourbon, fig, toffee, pomegranate, boozy. Nice.

I have actually had two taste tests of this beer- right after I bought it in December 2014 (When I laid in about a case) and then in late summer of 2015, a few months after its "best after" date. Since I love Deschutes beer, I was disappointed in the first taste. However, this beer was meant to age, and it

UPDATED: APR 22, 2016 Sample, brown bottle, 12%, best after 04/22/15, from and with Réjean Doiron (merci!), savoured on October 14 2015; eye: mahogany, clear, no effervescence, no head, no lacing; nose; woody, light caramel, slight molasses, slight caramel, slight Cointreau; nose: woody, light caramel, slight molasses, slight caramel, slight Cointreau, finale in malt with light presence of alcohol, medium-full body, below-average carbonation, mildly sweet, slick texture; overall: correct
 
FRANÇAIS
 
Échantillon, bouteille brune, meilleure après 04/22/15, de et avec Réjean Doiron (merci!), savourée le 14 octobre 2015; il : acajou, limpide, pas deffervescence, pas de mousse, pas de dentelle; nez : boisé, léger caramel, très léger mélasse, très léger caramel, très léger Cointreau; bouche : boisé, léger caramel, très léger mélasse, très léger caramel, très léger Cointreau, finale en malt avec légère présence dalcool, corps moyen-corsé, carbonatation sous la moyenne, moyennement sucrée, texture coulante; en résumé : correct
March 12, 2016 - on tap at Rare Beer Fest held in the Minnesota History Center. Reddish pour with limited head. Aroma was fruity, red wine and whiskey. Taste was a bit sugary sweet.

Bottle @ Home. Dark amber in color with a thin khaki head. Get a bit of high boost alcohol fumes to start. Wowe. Lots of sweet caramel, spiced cake, and a whole lot of grape/raisin. This is an intense beer in all facets. The mouthfeel leaves something to be desired, though...not much carbonation. Tastes kind of like brandy and rum, even. Oaky, sweet, and boozy. Not my jam.

Poured into a snifter.

3.5 A: Clear deep amber color. Under one finger of beige head formed and quickly fell without leaving any lacing.

4.25 S: Quite enticing. The pomegranate hits you hard, but its fruitiness does not run solo. Fig, date, and plum follow with some sweet orange peel. Vinous grape, vanilla, and oak. While I cant smell the rye whiskey directly, I can sense it is blending with the other flavors. Im not getting much spice from the nose, but thats probably because the pomegranate is so powerful.

4.0 T: The spice does come out well in the taste - peppery which complements the earthy rye spiciness and the subtle boozy heat. The wine barrel also is more potent as the vinous grape matches the power of the pomegranate. Again lots of plum, fig, and date to accompany. Vanilla and oak with a touch of tannic astringency.

4.5 M: Medium to heavier medium body. Good moderate carbonation with a spritziness that makes this light on the tongue. Warming boozy finish.

4.25 D: Very nice beer. It has some powerful flavors that all mesh well together all while being quite drinkable.

★ 1,118 characters


DavoleBomb, Oct 21, 2015

Aroma of bourbon, vanilla, caramel. Appearance is reddish brown, no head. Taste is dark fruit, caramel, vanilla, bourbon. Sweet candy. Sugary, coats my teeth. Slightly warming. Ok, for me. A tad sweet.

Tap at Pita Kabob in Visalia. Plum and dark fruit dominate. Sweet candi in the background. Pours a clear chestnut brown with off-white to light tan head. Taste is rich malt with thorough layering of raisin, dark fruit. A bitterness at the death is a little odd, but a great beer.
One of the best quads I've had. Very good and not over the top. ........................
Bottle..Pour is dark gold with a tan head.. Nose is oak, whiskey, pomegranate, spice, musty..Taste is oak, spice, berries, whiskey, grape skin, musty, sweetness, pomegranate...

Bottle, thanks for sharing! Pours a near clear reddish amber with a white head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has a good amount of fruit with sweet grains, caramel and a bit of flora. Flavor has flora and light fruits up front with sweet grains and caramel supporting.

750 ml bottle from Specs in Houston, drank at home. Strong aroma from barrels. Dark brown color with light brown head. God quad flavor with smooth additional taste from barrel aging. Very enjoyable. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

22oz bottle. Pours a lot of carbonation. No head. Alcohol, dark fruit, some chocolate. Very rich. Super rich flavors come together nicely. Body is a bit flat considering all the bubbles. Interesting brew with a lot of flavor.

22oz bottle in a glass. Pours amber/brown with an off-white head. Aroma of dark fruits, spicy yeast, some light oak and whiskey, molasses, light bitterness, and caramel and sweet malts. Flavor the same with a decent blend. Average texture. A decent quad but a little weird.

Dark brown coloured body with a muddy and ruby glow, all with a thick, fast-dying two centimetre tall light brown head. Aroma of alcohol, bourbon, rum, vanilla, oak, pit fruits and a lot of raisins, all with some malt notes as well. Medium-bodied; Very boozey flavour of rum, bourbon, oak, vanilla and grain with a very warming feeling right after a sip. Aftertaste shows some complexity with brown sugar, alcohol, roasted malt, raisins, oak and cognac noticeable as well. Overall, a very sweet and even more boozey flavour with some grain and malts noticeable, but the oak, warming feeling and especially the alcohol are the main aspects coming through on this one. A good to decent beer, but nothing amazing nor worth searching out/aging a bottle for. I sampled this 65 cL wax-capped bottle purchased from Total Wine in Alexandria, Virginia on 20-November-2014 for US$15,99 sampled at home in Washington on 15-December-2015, a bit more than a year after purchasing it. Best After Date on bottle of 22-April-2015, printed on label at 12,1% abv.

Sample from 2014 bottle at the Beer Tasting on 11/07/2015. Clear copper color with a medium off-white head that diminishes gradually. Patchy lacing on the glass. The aroma consists of bourbon, dark fruit and malt. Full-bodied with flavors of caramel malt, bourbon and fruit. The finish is vinous oak and bourbon. Good beer all around.
Tap at Dexters. Stained glass amber-brown caramel body. Deep red fruit. Sweet, deep red fruit tones. Depthful, balanced, restrained for 12%. Great Quad. Sweet. Well done.

Cloudy Amber pour with a quickly receding beige head .... Aroma is of candi sugar, dark fruits (plums), red wine, molasses and light whiskey notes smells for the most part of a quad .... Taste is of molasses, sugar plums, some dry red wine, grapes, candi sugar and a spicy rye whiskey on the backend .... Finished with a mix of dry oak, spicy rye whiskey, sweet plums and light wine .... Better than the stoic .... Mouthfeel is a little boozy and spicy... as it warms it gets spicier .... A quad barleywine brew in my humble opinion

Pours a mostly clear copper with a white head that settles to a film on top of the beer. Aroma of malt, brown sugar, fruit and yeast aromas. Taste is much the same with malt, brown sugar and fruit flavors on the finish with some booziness. Medium carbonation with a slightly crisp mouthfeel. A good beer that is like a barleywine. Enjoyed.

2015 bottle. Bronze beer with a dark cream head. Wine and bourbon aroma with light vanilla and light banana. Bourbon and oak flavor with dried fruit, light caramel, and light vanilla. Medium-plus bodied. Dried fruit and malt linger with light yeast and light bourbon.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

For the love of all that is good in this world, this is why I drink beer. Amber pour with an off-white head. Sweet, boozy tart aroma. Tastes of boozy bourbon, something tart, and a yeasty, malty BALANCED goodness. The barrels and wood are prominent but just enough, the alcohol is right there but perfectly placed, the tart fruity element is blending everything together in a beautiful orchestrated madness. One of my all time favorites with depth and complexity to contemplate for a long time.
At dominion wine and beer poured from a bottle it is a amber color with a slight head. The aroma is boozy and caramel. The taste is sweet with a strong bourbon flavor

Pours a deep mahogany with only a slight head - typical for a higher ABV brew such as this. A rich aroma of caramel and dark fruit, with hints of a fruity wine. Smooth a balanced on the palate, with a freshness that belies the hints of whiskey. Not quite as complex as it could be, but excellent nonetheless.

Bottle. Copper red. Dark fruit, molasses, licorice notes, toffee, caramel, vanilla. Thick and rich feel. Excellent. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Dark ruby with thin ring of off white head. Tons of dark fruit, cherry cordial, caramel, toffee. Thick and sticky. Really tasty.

Bottle: Poured a clear copper color ale with a nice foamy head. Aroma of molasses and residual sugar offset by some vinous notes and light vanilla whiskey notes. Taste is a mix of molasses and residual sugar notes with some dry fruits notes with some light vinous notes and light vanilla and whiskey notes. Body is lighter then I would have expected for the style with light warming alcohol notes. Interesting experiment but needs a fuller body and I would drop the wine barrels as well and concentrate on the whiskey barrels which are a better match for the base beer.

Bottle from Connectcut Wines DC. Pours amber with no head and no lacing. Nose is bourbon, plums. Flavours are plums, bourbon, syrup, booze. Taste is big sweet, light bitter. Mouth big body lively carbonation and very boozy.

A clear dark reddish copper ale with a thin mocha head. In aroma, sweet fruity caramel malt with candy sugar, light bourbon barrel, licorice notes, treacle, light solvent, very nice. In mouth, a nice sweet fruity malt with loads of candy sugar, treacle, alcohol warmth, goes well with burned caramel . Bottle from Rejtable.
Bottle. Pours dark brown tan head. Nose/taste of caramel, oak, dark fruit and alcohol - medium/full body.
22oz bottle pours a dark brown color without much head. Sweet caramel and some mild whiskey barrel.
Bottle. Brown pour with tan head. Fruit, sugars and yeast aromas. Belgian yeast, sugars and plum fruit tones.

22oz bomber shared at CBC Clerkenwell tasting, London. It pours a rich copper color with medium beige head. Aroma is sweet and lightly yeasty with notes of ripe fruits molasses apricots and caramel. Taste is also quite sweet and rich with milk chocolate ripe apricots caramel and vanilla. Medium to full bodied with good carbonation. Overall, really good

데슈츠 브루잉 - 낫 더 스토익 12% ABV 오크 케스크에 에이징된 콰드루펠 맥주.짙은 레드와인-코냑 계열에 위스키의 향이 피어오르는 조합으로,에이& 덕택에 하나하나 분리되기보단 전반적 무게감이 뛰어난 맥주 

벨기에 수도원 맥주 계열에서 가장 강력한 종류인 콰드루펠을 위스키 베럴에서 10개월이 넘도록 에이징 시켰으니 정말 극강의 조합인 듯. 피노누아르 와인 캐스크 버전과 호밀 위스키 캐스크 에이징 버전도 소량 생산되었으며 11개월 숙성에 도수는 15%라고.

특별히 하나하나 뽑아내며 깨닭는 즐거움 보다는 그냥 오랫동안 대화를 나누며 천천히 즐기기 좋은 난롯가의 맥주다. 비강에 남는 위스키 에이징 향이 강해 비흡연자지만 담배나 시가가 땡기기도 한다. 벨지언 스트롱 에일 특유의 단맛이 강해 호불호가 갈릴맥주

https://twitte

bomber shared nice quad aroma of very sweet malts and dark fruits. medium to heavy body with alcohol nicely hidden throughout. the dark fruits such as cherries and more pronounced plums come through in a big way and the alcohol warmth on the end makes this a very good quad. only drawback it is a little think in the body but not really a deterrent.
Very rich flavour, smells boozy but doesnt taste that way. Gently carbonated, playing to drink.

(Bottle) Dark, brownish red body with a medium, quickly light brown head. Aroma is fruity, vinous, wood and whiskey; sweet and strong alcohol. Medium body, oily mouthfeel. Sweet, mild tartness (pomegranate/grape/cherry), molasses, light wood. Would like it even more if a bit less sweet, but very good nonetheless--I like the combinations going on.

22 ounce bottle, label says 12.1% ABV, best after 04/22/15. Served in a DFH Signature Glass, the beer pours a hazy reddish/brown color with about a half inch light tan head that stayed around for a while. Theres also a good amount of lacing. The brew smells like dark fruit, molasses, pomegranate, oak and some rye whiskey. I think the taste is similar to the aroma, but with the addition of red grapes/wine and bready malt. The booziness seems to be well hidden in this, it sure doesnt taste like its 12%. Mouthfeel/body is medium/full, its coating and smooth with a moderate amount of carbonation. I thought this was a good Quad, I wouldnt mind picking up another bottle if I came across one again.

22 oz bottle, Best After 04/22/15, just now getting around to it- Pours dark ruby red with a light tan head that reduces. Aroma is oak, bourbon, dark fruits, musty grapes, very nice. The taste is oak, vanilla, dark fruits, id say cherry, but could be pomegranate, light chocolate, it reminds me of the Firestone Walker Anniversary beers, that toasted coconut flavor that mingles with the barrel, alcohol is noticeable, leaving a warming feeling. Yum!!
Bottle from bevmo. Pours dark ruby with tan head. Aroma of dark fruits. Taste is some Belgian yeast, figs, raisins roasted malts.

Pours a nice merkey brown,cola color. A very nice thin tan head that disappears quickly. The aroma hits you as soon as you open the bottle. A toasty malt. Taste is dark fruit, raisins, yes you can taste pomegranate. A hint of rye whisky. This is very good!!

Bomber courtesy of Wilkes and Lynn. brown pour, beige head. aroma is plum, sugar, molasses. tastes are same - sweet sweet burnt sugar. its sweet. its boozy. get a fair bit of the wine. drinks smoother than how big it is. but still way too sweet for me.
Nice aroma and flavor of bready malt, molasses and yeast. Deep brown color and a good weight. Strong and slightly boozy.

Bomber. Clear dark brow, large fizzy brown head, poor retention. Aroma of whiskey, dark fruits, caramel, bread, molasses, maple, mild oak. The taste is whiskey, dark fruits, caramel, oak, molasses. Medium bodied, low carbonation. Decent.

Bottle [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Clerkenwell, London (03/06/2015) - dark brown coloured pour with beige head. Medium sweet malty aroma and taste, toasty, caramel, toffee, brown sugar, dried fruity and nutty, some spices on the palate, medium sweet bitter finish. Really liked this.

Bottle split at the 9.49 CBC boost tasting, Clerko, 03/06/15 thanks to Padraig G-boig.
Lightly hazed chestnut brown with a decent tan covering.
Nose is rich dark fruit rinds, pear drop, spice, tangy fruit wash, toasted brown sugar, prune juice, light barrel.
Taste comprises dates, fruit cake mix, sweet and sour notes, light wood, prune, fruit rind, light candy bar, tarte red grape.
Medium + bodied, fine carbonation, lightly warming alcohol in the close.
Solid quad, masks the ABV well @sipper.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Small compact head that dissipates quickly. Nice aromas of vanilla and oak. Rich and satisfying. Delicious.

Bottle shared at craft beer co clerko. With thanks to Manny G-unit. Bright amber reddy coloured pour with a loose off white head. Aroma is spicy cinnamon, nutty dried fruits, alcohol and dried apple. Flavour is composed of tart apple, toffee, honey, toast, Belgian yeast. Palate is full sticky, warming alcohol. Palate is sticky, sweet, highish carbonation. Lingering warming alcohol, and cinnamon apple pie.

Bottle share at CBC Clerkenwell, thanks to Padraig. Dark orange / brown, lightly sparkling, small foamy white head. Aroma is very sweet caramel, toffee, musty toffee apple. Body is medium, slightly foamy, tingly carbonation. Taste is sweet with caramel, toffee apple and liquorice. Alcohol coming through a fair bit, soft bitterness to finish.

Bottle thanks to Manny G. It pours clear deep reddish-brown with a medium beige head. The nose is toasty, woody, cinnamon bun, toffee, varnish, plenty of soft fruits and berry. The taste is slick, sweet, toffee apple, dried apricot, raisin, booze, toasted brown sugar, caramelised banana, wood, light spice and fruit cake with some warmth towards the finish. Medium-full body, moderate carbonation and foamy mouth-feel. Rich, slick and boozy. Rather decent if a touch sweet.
A very good quad. Lots of fruitiness and spice here. Apple, caramel, nutmeg, plum, and sugar. Tried with Anthony after the DK200 in 2015

Bottle shared in London - thanks to Padraig. Pours clear copper with a a frothy tan head. Lots of ripe fruits in the nose, caramel, berries. Heavy sweet flavor with lots of fruitcake, toffee, subtle booze. Medium to full bodied with fine carbonation. Warming finish, more toffee, ripe fruits, berries. Solid.
Its a good beer with its strength well hidden, but all of the other claimed attributes, while may be present, are not obvious.
Tan bubbly appearance, carbonated light temporary head, wood cherry raisin flavors, medium body golds together

Dark garnet pour with a on finger, creamy beige head. Aroma is dark fruit, vinous tartness, and molasses up front, then sweet bread crust, fig jam, light, toasty oak, a touch of vanilla, dark caramel and a hint of chocolate. Flavor is red wine-like vinous notes, husky grain, dark caramel, oaky notes (more toasty and less vanilla that the aroma), lots of dark fruit, spicy hops, tart berry notes, pleasant, but fairly strong boozy notes. Medium to heavy body, syrupy to chewy entry, medium, blanketing and somewhat sharp carbonation and still chewy, but somewhat creamy yet dry finish. Good stuff overall, I really like the surprisingly well balanced barrel aging notes, just enough to add some complexity without being overpowering.

A purple/maroon color. A dark fruit nose. Little carbonation and lacing. I dont think the aging in wine oak barrels did this beer any favors. The wine presence is too strong for my personal preference.

Aroma: caramel, dark fruit
Appearance: brown, clear, tan foam, 
Taste: medium sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, dark fruit
Palate: full body, thick feel, soft carbonation, long finish, 

Excellent

Bomber sampled at Classic City Brew Fest 2015! Pours a hazy copper brown with dissipating off-white head that leaves light lace. Aroma of big dark fruit, hint of Belgian esters, sweet tannins. Taste follows, hint of sour cherry, great for the style. Boozy sweetness, but not over the top. Really nice beer.

Wax-dipped bomber. Best After 4/22/15. Aroma is oaky, coconut, vanilla, cookie dough, red licorice, brown sugar, dark fruits. Pours cloudy amber with a one finger beige head that collapses fairly quick. Taste starts out sweet and cookie-like before dark fruit, imparting some tartness, alcohol, tobacco, leather and licorice kick in. Full-bodied oily mouthfeel. Really tasty.

Big bottle with commonmac and rosskyle. Dark plum with small white head. Dark fruit tartness in the nose, smells somewhat sour. Raisin and dark fruit, tangy bite. Little bits of yeast funk, lots of alcohol taste. Sour dark fruit and raisin dominates but in a good way. Fits the style very well.

Dark red color. Sweet plum aroma. Sweet wine flavor. Clean finish. Flavor lingers.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

I'm a big fan of barrel aged beers and this is a good choice. The best thing about it is a wonderful aftertaste. The alcohol taste is slightly strong. 

- Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottled. Dark pour with pretty smallish head. Fruity pomegranate. Cherries. Dark chocolate. Pretty good.

22oz bottle, poured into a snifter. The nose is full of roasted notes with undertones of caramel, dried fruit, woody bourbon, herby spice, a light vanilla, and further down, candy sugar, with a late touch of acetone warmth. Its a deep and oily orange-brown, amber with sediment thats topped by a foamy, soapy head. It retains a medium thin ring, some surface wisps, and a light, dense lace. The taste is a high sweetness complimented by a medium high bitter. The beer is thick and oily with a fuzzy carbonation. The full body contains a dominant flavor of dried fruit, with complimentary notes of wood and spice and a caramel character that strengthens near the end of the bottle. It finishes spicy and dry with a fruity zest. Its crisp with a nice alcohol warmth on the way down. The aftertaste is astringent with waxy citrus peel and light notes of toffee and wood.

Bottle of the 2015 vintage (12.1% abv) best after 4/22/15. A reddish brown color with a quickly laced tan head. A strong fruit aroma with with caramel, light wood, raisins, plums, and a touch of red wine. Sweet and powerful.

Bomber poured a clear reddish amber with a lasting amber head. Aromas of dried fruit, toffee, vinous notes, light oak and a hint of cocoa. Palate was medium bodied and smooth with a dry finish. Flavors of toffee, oak, light sherry and light fruitiness with a smooth dry lingering toffee finish.
Mahogany pour with a dissipating beige head. Aroma is dark fruit, wine. Taste is very fruity, pomegranate, darker fruits, dry, oaky, a little spicy. It was easy to drink, a little creamy. Very tasty.
Hazy brown pour with tan head. Aroma is plum and molassus. Taste follows.nose. a bit overly sweet.

Rouge mahogany body, mild haze, thin light khaki head. Huge sweet dark fruit aroma with prominent plums, raisins, overly ripe prunes. Super sweet with prevalent alcoholic heat. Red wine, red grapes, sweet grape juice. The quad character is totally lost here. Too sweet and overbearing. Not a fan.

Look: pours a dark Amber. Slightly cloudy. Light brown head.
Smell: sweet cherries. Caramel. Wine. Slight sour. 
Taste: brown sugar. Caramel. Cherries. Plum. 
Feel: thin mouth feel. Slightly dry finish. 
Overall: great beer. Like the balance. Sour yet sweep. Nice hops but good malts.
First drank: home 2/13/15
Vintage: best after 4/22/15
On draft. Dark ruby color with little head. Dark fruit and boozy aroma. Sweet and dark fruit taste. Really smooth for the abv. Very good beer.
Pours beautiful reddish brown. Aroma is massive dark fruit molasses and boozy. Taste is lots of bourbon Barrell booziness and that fruity molasses. Really quality stuff
Bottle, thanks Adam! Pours red/brown, with a tan head. Aroma is malt, sugar, red wine, fruit, and some alcohol. Flavor is sugar, malt, fruit, wine, and oak. Medium body.
not being a huge fan of Belgian style beers, this is one of the best Ive had. Smooth, complex, nice carbonation, hides the high abv dangerously well
Dark cherry and plum aroma . Taste has notes of black currant, lavender, leather. Finish is sweet.
again beautiful...nose is booze and fruit...way tasty quad....again a really nice beer....
Draft at Bricks. Pours ruby brown with no head. Nose is plum and oak. Taste adds vanilla and vineous notes. Alcohol comes through the nose in the aftertaste.

On tap 10oz pour into tulip. Minneapolis. 

Pours cloudy brown with slight red hue. Aroma is brown sugar, fig, alcohol, a little woody. Taste is sweet, dry mild bitterness in the finish. Full bodied, soft carbonation, long finish. For a quad this was pretty decent. Sweeter than I was expecting. Something was a little off- could have been the wine barrel aging.

I really appreciated the extra oak and whiskey notes in this one; the original needed it. Love that they realized an opportunity to continue refining an already-released beer and went with it. Sweeter and a bit drier, perhaps a tinge of heat. Very tasty; better than the original.

This was a delicious first try of a Deschutes Brewery offering and I wasnt disappointed. The pomegranate molasses is pleasant on the palate with an almost vanilla fume and gives a nice contrast to the slight maltiness. Essence of funk in there too.
22 oz bottle. Brown in color with a good sized beige head. Aroma is of berry, oak, vinous, malt, booze, vanilla. Taste is of oak, vanilla, booze, vinous, caramel, and prune.

Bottle. The look is cloudy, brown color with some redness, beige colored head. The smell is fruity, toffee, sweet, molasses, sugar, alcohol, oak, wine like, and nice. The taste is sweet, burnt sugars, prunes, plums, wine, wood, and fruits.

Bottle: gift from wife. Poured a dark auburn color with a tannish head. Aroma of molasses, cherries, cookies, dark fruit and alcohol. A bit hot upfront, but goes away. Flavor varied throughout. Molasses and a fruity sweetness; caramel, dark fruit and wine notes. Very good

Pours a dark brown/black color with a tiny head. Aroma is sweet dark fruit, Belgian candy sugar, and cherries. The taste is thick and sweet. Lots of Belgian candy sugar, raisins, dark fruits, alcohol and a touch of cherry cough syrup (in a good way). Very good.
It poured a dark amber color with an off-white head. The aroma was of raisins, vanilla and oak. The flavor was of dark fruits, molasses, fig, raisins, cherry, bread and oak. Awesome.

Poured from a bomber into goblet. I haven't really been into Belgians recently but ended up liking this. It's not overtly a Belgian quad. The yeast is muted and there are many other flavors going on to take you away from your typical quad expectations. For fans of the style, this may be a bad thing. The bourbon barrel aging was well done, with a bit of whiskey on the back end. The wine barrel and pomegranate gave the whole beer a nice subtle tartness that went well with the fruitiness. A good and very interesting beer.

22oz bottle picked up at the state store 
Pours hazy brown with a small beige head, light lacing. Aroma is dark fruit, wet wood, sweet caramel and oak. Flavors are woody, dark malts, caramel, dark fruit and bourbon 
Very nice, smooth and well balanced. No hot alcohols. I like this one.
Beautiful mahogany color. Big dark fruit, slight vanilla and wood on the nose. Sugary, alcohol. Taste is similar. Less on the alcohol. Rye comes through slightly in the finish. Medium full body.
UPDATED: DEC 1, 2014 Dark fruit, plum, oak, vanilla, spices. Beautiful mahogany color. Good mouthfeel, decently complex. Though not worth the price tag.

Tap at Busters. Snifter glass. Mahogany, plum color with healthy but non-persistent head. Dark fruit is predominantly the aroma with a near whiskey presence felt. Taste is strongly plum and raisin with an overwhelming quad sweetness. You can feel the alcohol but it doesnt override the quality flavor notes. Really solid mouthfeel. A little burn at the end but overall impressed.

Draft. Poured clear dark copper color with an average frothy off-white head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate to heavy complex dark fruit and woody aroma. Medium to abundant body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy dark sweet flavor with a medium to heavy sweet finish of moderate to long duration. My expectations were met with a solid brew.

Tap: Glad to find this on tap as my cheap ass never was willing to shell out 17$ for a bomber. Ruby red with mahogany highlights, semi-clear & rimmed with a thin, beige collar. Aroma has notes of toasted rye crackers, prune, black cherry drizzled with caramel, moderately vinous red grape skins, faint toffee coated red apple, & a good bout of residual sugar sweetness from front to back. Flavor carries through with a nice caramel apple vibe, mild hints of butterscotch & vanilla popping in & out in a controlled manner. More complex notes of maple, Candi sugar, & vinous oak lead into a slightly booze forward, red wine-like finish. Decent heat for 12% ABV. Quite enjoyable.

Tap. Dark brown with purplish highlights, wispy tan head. Nose is dark berry, plum, molasses, a little vanilla from the barrels. Sweet palate; intensely fruity, sugary, fairly light-bodied texture. Decent beer right now, though I do wonder if this will have improved by the "best after" date.

Lots of fruit sweet boozy aroma. Pours a cloudy dark reddish brown with a thin light tan head that fizzes away. The Pinot is very evident right up front. It fades to some fruitiness and ends with a woodiness and boozy warmth. Very smooth. Relatively thin. Dry red wine finish.

Draft at Ei8ht Ball. Pours a clear dark amber brown color with a thin off white film. The aroma and flavor have big sweet Belgian candi sugar, sweet, fruity, light woody, the pinot noir influence began very mild and increased slightly with warming, a slight spicy rye bite at the finish, the problem is the big sweetness, as it warmed it calmed down a little.
Shared bomber to snifters. Mahogany pour. Long lasting ring. Sweet and malty. Some fruity wine and pepper on the finish.
Sweet, somewhat boozy barleywine aroma. Deep brown, clear, and headless. Taste is rich and worry, with vanilla bourbony notes. $6/12oz

Bottle @ home, via the rotbox. Pours a clear, deep reddish orange appearance with a very thin tan head. Some retronasal burn. Red grapes, raisins, plums, and burnt caramel in the nose. The flavor has some whiskey and a little bit of booze. Quite a bit of grapes, plums, and dates. Theres an almost cognac note to the flavor along with a bit of honey roasted pecans. A little syrupy and the carbonation is kind of dull. Pretty fucken decent. High boost.

On tap: The aroma consists of dark fruits, bourbon, spice, vanilla, light oak, and a touch of alcohol. Its a dark brown with orange transparency and a small off-white ring for a head. The flavor starts with dark fruits, raisin, and some faint lemon. The finish has light vanilla, lavender, and a touch of sour oak. Its medium bodied with mild carbonation and a slightly sticky mouthfeel.

Bottle. Pours reddish brown with a small tan head. Aroma of dark fruit, caramel, oak, vanilla and raisins. Rich and complex flavor with caramel, dark fruit, oak, toffee, vanilla, molasses, raisins and brown sugar.
Superb quad. Dark fruit notes that I look for are here in abundance. No alcohol burn.
Draft. Heavy raisin/dark fruit, spices, some various barrel flavors, booze. Decent.

Good night -- what a complex, delicate, beauty of a beer. The winelike notes of the barrels come right through, and at 12 percent, this beer delivers the complexity befitting the inexcusable amount of alcohol it delivers.

Pours ruby red with a small tan head. Smells fruity, caramel, hints of bread and sugar. Taste is dark fruit, sweet, hints of the barrels. Full-bodied with a smooth texture and soft mouth-carbonation, Deschutes Not the Stoic finishes with a lingering fruity sweetness.

Bottle from Mane Liquor. Pours murky brown with a sticky beige head. Nose is very tarty and red berry forward with plenty of bourbon and spice present over the top of a malty base. The vibrant sweetness of the red berries is quite in-your-face and I really like it. The taste shows these bright red berries coming out in front of some sour cherry, vanilla sweetness, wood and mild spice. Bourbon has a fairly high focus in this and since Im a bourbon lover it is definitely for me! Really like the combination of tartiness and bourbon vanilla-spice notes. Combines so well and really comes across balanced. Drinks far too easily for 12%. World class stuff

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2015 This is going to be a fun one. one for today, and one for 6 months down the road, will post ratings for both to see if really is best after...
Poured with shakey hands,12 hours with nothing but coffee and some cheap irish cream apparently makes my hands tremble, good to know. Not much of a head even with my palsey, deep marroon body with some small bubbles showing that this is not angels share. Boozed up red wine nose with definite barrel notes. should know if my stove will get a full boil going before i finish this beer, then i can figure out homebrewing supplies in New Mexico! Molasses, strawberry, and red wine hit me first, warming alcohol, followed by light vanilla, a very faint wood note, much less than i expected after smelling this. lingering raisin and some tannin like bitterness from the wine notes. just a hint of the floral earthy hops in there that are working well to allow the malt to shine. no real yeast notes apparent to me. something like marshmallows emerge in the finish as this warms, and the nose really opens up to give a more pronounced wine taste. bit of spice and sweet alcohol really gets better the slower i drink this. a fun one to sip on for an hour or so.

rerate 5/3 from same batch. pours a dark amber brown with a big grey head. smells of berries and booze with a caramel hint. warming flavor of alcohol, strawberry, and a bunch of caramel. light bitterness that is a bit pineapple like. muffin like bread notes throughout this with a bit of pepper and just a touch of a blood like flavor. a reat sipper i have spent just shy of 3 hours enjoying. made a point of not reading my initial review as i did not want to taint my notes on the older version, really enjoyed this. last rating was 7 2 7 3 16 . this one is a 6 4 7 4 17

Bottle thanks to MacBoost. Pours with a large off white head. Fairly clear dark red color. Nose is fruity and Belgian with some dried fruits. Taste is smooth, thin, a it of cherry and wood with some vanilla. The alcohol comes through in the end. Pretty good boost.
murk amber. Light head. Nose is boozy and full of orange peel and oak. Taste is difficult. Its a very boozy beer bits of cigar ash and charcoal
Bottle. Pours brown with red hues and off-white head. Aroma is very figgy, raisins, sweet, brown sugar. Taste is raisins and figs, thinner than most quads, medium bodied, not too sweet. Very good.,

Bomber at home. Pours dark brown with a light brown head that disappeared quickly. Aroma is dark malt, wine, fruit and bourbon. Taste is malt, alcohol, bourbon and a hint of licorice. Medium body with a smooth sweet finish. Very good.

On tap @ 10 East (Deschutes Tap Takeover) 

Aroma - cherry juice, tobacco leaves, dark fruit with port like notes 

Appearance - mahogany brown body, ruby edges, 1-finger beige head, no retention 

Mouthfeel - medium body, light/medium carbonation, silky 

Flavor - very vinous, oaky, sweetish and acetone-y. Complex would be a good description but the sweetness is a bit much at times. 

Overall - an excellent beer and happy I got to try it on tap. Another winner for Deschutes.

Pours a deep brown with a small tan head. The aroma is dark malt, prune, wine, and alcohol. The flavor is dark malt and dark fruit with a sweet, wine and bourbon finish over a medium-heavy body.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
ABR 2014. Sweet caramel and malt flavor. Sweet. Not particularly recognizable as as quad, and I did not pick up on the whiskey barrel. I did perceive some of the wine.

A very nice boozy quad. Pours a beautiful deep ruby red with a tan head. Smells malty, with some cherry and spices, cinnamon. Taste is creamy, herby and not as malty as the nose would suggest. Bit of a tart, green apple finish. Had in the bottle.
Draft at Imbibe Wine. Nose is vanilla, raisins, and candisugar. Lightly hazy brown with a medium heavy lacing beige head. Flavor is lightly sweet, dark fruitiness, and light vanilla oak. Nicely done!

Clear dark purpley brown with a fast-dissipating head. Rummy yet winey nose with a touch of oak and molasses and touches of raisin. Good semisweet flavor of red wine oak and molasses, a touch of raisin, rummy brown sugar and a boozy finish of dates. Some rye whiskey tones shine as it warms up.

Aromas of fruit, molasses and bourbon. Pours a clear deep reddish brown with no head or lacing. The taste is sweet malt, sugar, molasses, hints of wood and vanilla, dark fruit and a slight flavor of bourbon. Medium-full body and moderate carbonation. Round smooth mouthfeel. Overall, an excellent sipper. Rich, smooth and rewarding.

Dark amber/cider color; Medium creamy body; Aroma of toasted sweet malt, yeast, vanilla, dark fruit, & some whiskey/bourbon; Flavor of sweet malt, yeast, caramel, molasses, dark fruit (notably plums & grapes), and some vanilla; Warm smooth finish; Nicely balanced and fairly light; Well crafted - very tasty.

On tap at Capitol Beer & Tap Room. Pours dark brown with a nice tan head and a sweet treacle aroma. There is a rich dark molasses flavor with a hint of pomegranate and lots of whiskey. A great sipper.
Powerful initial aroma, head dissipates very quickly, strong classic quad flavor, nice wood notes, and beautiful mouthfeel.

Bottle:   Burgundy, deep caramel hues, thin to moderate frothy tannish head, spotty lacing.   Big bready aroma, dark pitted fruit, a touch of black cherry.   Big and rich on the tongue, sweet, almost cloying but just shy, bready, dark pitted fruit, a bit musty, some basement.   Interesting example.   Fairly full bodied.   Finishes like it started, perhaps a little anise in there too.   Does seem to have a slight vinous touch on the finish.   Does fall off quick after the finish, soft pinot noir notes linger.   Interesting take on the style.

Quite the looker, maroon with a thin white head. Nice aroma of malt and wood. The is sweet with a nice balance, quad like with some Belgium spice. Sticky and rich with a nice warming of the throat. A sipper and best suited for the cold weather to come

Draught. Pours a clear reddish brown color with a small off-white head on there. Nose has some candy, dark fruit elements, and a bit of whiskey to it. Taste is slightly sweet and slightly fruity, and ends up being remarkably light.

Dark maroon body with brown head, quickly fading, some lacing. Cola and welches grape juice aroma, bubblegum and vanilla, dried fruit. Awesome dried fruit taste, rich and very malty, without being too sweet. Awesome quad.
22 ounce bottle. Pours a dark golden orange with a decent off-white head. Aroma of fruit, yeast, wood, and caramel. Taste is dark fruit, yeast, oak, caramel, and alcohol. Very well done.

Bottle, shared by heavyleavy at game night. Beautiful deep red-orange with a two-finger thick beige head. Aroma is rich sweet malt and red fruits, spicy and boozy undertones. Sweet palate, toffee malts, dates, ripe banana, dark red fruits (plums?cherries?), with smooth oak coming in late. Finish is warming without being harsh. Superb.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: From a 22 oz bottle shared at home. Pours a clear deep amber with an ecru head. Caramel and banana lacquer nose. Flavors of dark fruits. Medium bodied. Smooth lush finish.

Bombers from Capones and Whole Foods Plymouth. Pours hazy ruby with a finger of tan head. Nose is oak, caramel, molasses, berry fruit, hops, rye. Tastes merloty, oaky, hoppy, carsmelly and fruity, like an amalgam of red wine grapes, oak, rye, whisky, and hops. This one is as unique as I have encountered, and the best example of a beer that straddles the beer/wine/spirit triple point of ANY beer I have quaffed. This one is great.

"Hmmmm. Interesting reboot of what I thought was an utterly FANTASTIC brew in The Stoic. Not a traditional quad, by any stretch...but I liked it far better than most quads. This one is pretty damn tasty too, though a step or two back in the awesomeness department and complexity. Pours darker, more like traditional quads, and smells more traditional as well, though sweeter. The rye whiskey and wine have a harder time coming through this one. The beer is around the same abv, but smells and tastes FAR stronger than its predecesor. Big fruity zesty bready yeast, and pomegranate. The fruit adds flavor, but not depth. Sweet warming in finish is nice, but I cant help compare. Its 0.3 points lower and $4 more than The Stoic, so the bottles I have now will be all :("

Bottle. Bronze beer with a dark cream head. Wine and bourbon aroma with light vanilla and light banana. Bourbon and oak flavor with dried fruit, light caramel, and light vanilla. Medium-plus bodied. Dried fruit and malt linger with light yeast and light bourbon.

Bottle (22oz): Pours a clear dark reddish color with a small tan head. Pretty light body, kind of wine like. Somewhat sweet and sticky, but not too much. Very tasty overall. This one was dated better after 4/22/15. I think I will get some more and keep them longer.

Draft. Clear ruby brownish color. Fair off-white head. Toasty. Pretty dry. Light medium body. Light Toffee. Caramel. Oak. Minimal barrel besides that it seemed.. Just barely enough fruitiness and sweetness. I dont know whats up with it but I seemed to have a much different experience with this beer than others have. Almost seemed to be watered down... I dont know.

As of late I can not find the time to take tasting notes of each beer I sample. I would like to track and record my thoughts of each so I will just use the simple scoring rubric until more time is available.

Pours dark ruby brown with one finger light tan head. Aroma dark fruits/Belgian yeast. taste dark fruits, plums, vinous notes, oak, bread, whiskey. Quite spicy, almost peppery at times. Finish prolonged dark fruits. full palate. Mild alcohol burn.
Really well done, better than the Stoic. The underlying quad is very good and is enhanced by the treatments.

On tap at PIB, pours a cloudy dark orangey amber with a small beige head. Aroma brings out lots of Belgian yeast, followed by feint toffee and dark fruits. Flavour is complex, with notes of toffee, brown sugar, and banana. Quite complex, and quite a bit better than The Stoic. Well-balanced and not too sweet. Very good unauthentic quad.

Beautiful dark ruby pour with just a small beige head. Aroma is molasses, pomegranate, raisin, fig, with notes of wine and oak. Flavor is molasses and dark fruits with hints of wine and whiskey barrel. This is a very complex beer. Sweet and flavorful. Finish is slightly boozy but to be fair I popped this brew before the suggested date on the bottle I bet this will age nicely. Very respectable.
22 ounce bottle. Sweet raisin with touch of plum/chocolate. Cola mixed in. Somewhat wine in nature.

Tap at Toronado w Erica. Pours deep dark red, smooth beige head in flute glass. Lacing is frosty and even but disappears almost immediately. Aroma of sweet malt bordering tart, palate chock full of chocolate raisin with a lingering candy quality and faint notes of toffey. Medium-bodied, high carbonation.

Clear reddish-brownish-amber with almost no head; just some beige bubbles sitting on top. Aroma of cherry (probably pomegranate), oak, red wine, grape jelly, vanilla, and whiskey. The taste is fruity, sweet, and a little boozy with nice contributions from the whiskey and, in particular, the pinot barrels. Medium-full bodied with soft carbonation. Solid; nicely not overdone.

Draft at SB. Pours a murky dark brown with a loose tan head that fades quickly. Nose shows lots of wood right away, big vanilla and spice, almost would have guessed rum barrels but thats probably just the molasses talking. The vinous notes are there, but the whiskey notes are very subdued. Creamy thick body with soft carb. Dark pitted tree fruit on the mid palate, also showing plenty of toasty oak, soft sweet molasses notes, and a light touch of jammy wine grape. Long sweet finish.

Aroma is light, almost non-existent. No warning to the amount of alcohol you are about to be presented (12%). The color is a gorgeous dark ruby. Quite amazing. The taste and palette reflect the pomegranate molasses as well as the barrel casking in aged Rye and Pinot Noir. Similar to Boulevards Rye on Rye, but possibly more refined. Sweeter than many Quads, this is an ale that could convert the ideological.

Dark ruby pour with small off white head. Aroma of ripe fruits, caramel, yeast, slight oak, and faint red wine. Taste of raisins, caramel, pears, banana, figs, molasses, faint oak and faint red wine. Full bodied, medium carbonation, perfectly balanced. Sweet but not cloying at all, absolutely delicious! Awesome beer!

Pours a light mahogany color with a puffy off white head. Notes of fake cake, vanilla, rye whiskey, grape jelly, and baked bread. Nice sticky mouthfeel and long finish. Comes across a little boozy and hot.

Bottle from total wine Tucson. Aroma is huge raisin, fig, molasses and sweet malts. Pour is dark brown. Tan head. Flavors are awesome. Sweet plums, molasses, figs, port wine, sweet. very nice. Complex and great.
Really complex. Has a lot of flavors going on. The aroma was nice. My only complaint may be the wine barrells came through a bit much.

Not a big fan of quads. This one was ok. I hate to rate it so poorly, but there was to much red wine taste for my liking. The aroma was enticing, but thats about the only thing about the beer I enjoyed.
Lots of caramel color, flavor and everything inbetween. Looks like cognac. Tastes better when its colder.

Not usually a fan of Belgian quads but this is an exception cause the flavor profile is very much like a barleywine which I love. Had on tap at Deschutes in downtown Portland. Sorry guys, i just threw back a Wootstout 2 and presently drinking a Pliny at Hamiltons in San Diego. Not the Stoic is the bomb. Get it if you like barleywines as it's a Belgian quad with a multi-layered flavor profile. You won't be disappointed.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On draft at Tap 25. It pours a rather clear dark amber color with a creamy off white head. The aroma is full with sweet fruit cake, raisins, vanilla and oak. The flavor is full with over ripe dark fruits and some hints of baking spice. Rich fig, raisins, cherry, bread and oak. Mild fruity acidity. A little alcohol and fruit bread in the finish. Very warming and satisfying. Well brewed.

650ml bottle. Pours a hazy deep ruby, with a smallish light beige head, which lasts well and leaves a little lacing. Fruity, sweet pomegranate molasses and pinot noir mix nicely in an aroma that also offers plum and musk notes and an underpinning oakiness. Mild spice hops up front are soon overcome by sweet plummy notes and the slightly tart sweetness of pomegranate. Oaky pinot leads into the finish, which is full of the warmth and spice of rye whiskey. There is undoubtedly an unusual combination of ingredients in this beer, but they work together extremely well, and meld effectively with the dark sweetness of a quad. An excellent piece of brewing.

Pours a very dark amber color with a white head. Sweet malt, caramel, dark fruit, molasses and aroma. Plum, raisin, molasses, malt, and alcohol flavors. Full body and average carbonation with a dark fruit and molasses finish.
Reddish brown with very light head. Light sweet smells. Almost cherry sweet with a light yeast. Leaves a lasting sweet from behind with a solid body. Wish a bit more of the rye came through.

On Tap at BitterCreek Ale House on Deschutes "not" tap Take Over Have just finished The Stoic, this one is bigger, boozier and not quite as sweet as its predecessor. Lots of classice dark Belgian fruit flavors, raisin and plum, some ripe banana and a significant ABV burn at the end. Drier finish than the non-not.
Dark golden amber pour with just a hint of head. Grape oak and bourbon nose. Spiced, big malt and lots of fruit, plum, raisin. Nice.

Darker reddish brown, moderate head, decent lace/retention. Aroma is sweet sugar, caramel, yeast, vanilla, darker fruit like raisin. Medium to full bodied, alcohol hidden fairly well. Not really true to the style.
Dark brown in color thin head - Big amount of dark fruit, raisin, prune, fig, brown sugar, toffee, and caramel. Dark, roasted malt, Big beer and tasty in my opinion.

Loads of dark fruit, raisin, prune, fig, brown sugar, toffee, and caramel. Dark, toasted malt, but not terribly complex compared to others in the style. Enjoyable but still less than world-class. Solid.

A barly wine aroma with a woody aroma come from this beautiful ruby red crystal clear brew with an off white head. Smooth sweet dry peppery taste up front then a sweet red wine finish with good carb and a plesant good to sip by a fire. Grear beer.

On tap at JL Beers. Beautiful dark ruby colour with a small tan head. Smells like red wine aged in a whiskey barrel and a bit of yeast, very enticing. Flavour is red wine with good tannins, very oaky, some yeast, dark fruits and a touch of whiskey. Wow. This was very tasty.

Bomber from Binnys. Dark fruit aromas with hints of wine. : Dark brown with a tan head that dissipates quickly. Light sweetness balanced by a light sourness in the finish. Palate: Medium body, thick texture, soft carbonation, long finish. Overall, Rich and complex tastes, very much like a well aged wine. Very solid beer.

Aroma of red fruit, booze, candi sugar, raisins, oak, and acid. Oh yeah, definitely a dark strong Belgian sort. A little strong in the sugar, though. Appearance: brown, purple, ruby hues. Almost no head. Taste: mostly red and purple fruit. Oak. Yeast. Not as sweet or acidic as I was anticipating based on the aroma, which is good. Booze is of course there, but doesnt overpower. A little thin and watery for the style, however. Is this an outstanding example of its style? No, but its good, and a good boozy Belgian is always better than most beers in my book.

I guess I dont fully understand what is different between this and the Stoic. If anything this seemed to be a bit more full in every department, but Id really need to do a vertical to make sure. Pomegranate was nicely present throughout which was nice.

Tap @ Deschutes Bond St. Pub in Bend, OR... Poured deep dark, mahogany-brown with a thin, light khaki head. Aroma of toasted/burnt toffee sugars with dense dark fruits. Big date/fig fruitiness with lots of sweetness and booze. Thick mouthfeel, dense barrel character even for just partially aged. Lots of vanilla and pastry/cake-like desert quality.

Clear dark ruby with bright red highlights, one-finger beige head and very nice lace. Wonderful deep cherry and red wine aromas accompanied by raisin, fig, oak and brown sugar. Smell carries over in the taste, with a tart red wine flavor followed quickly by oak/whiskey, banana, clove, and dark fruit sweetness. Medium bodied, nicely carbonated, warming alcohol, and a pleasant lingering sweetness. 

Time stamp: The Kings just won the Cup!
Red brown pour light tan head. Aroma of raisins cola. Tastes like a trippel some cough syrup from pomegranate molasses. big Belgian yeast and tobacco flavors.
Slightly reddish brown. Aroma of cherry, grapes, and booze. Flavors of burnt caramel, dried prunes, light vanilla, surprising tartness, and hot finish. Complex little number.

Im not a huge fan of the style, but I have to give it to Deschutes for producing a superb exemplar. All the classical qualities are here: big dark fruits, medium full mouthfeel, big carbonation, slightly tart finish. It tastes fresh and delightful at the same time. It is sweet without being cloying, and the tart cherryesque finish is just on the money. Very, very good job. Up there with the Belgian heavy hitters in the style!

Draft at the brewery. Dark mahogony color. Aroma of cherries, dark fruit, bourbon barrel, caramel. Medium heavy body. Awesome quad. Complex. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pour out of 750 mL bottle, dark reddish brown pour with white head, aroma brought big molasses, dark fruit, cherry, berry, hints of whiskey, spice, rye in there into a touch of dark cocoa, pretty sweet smelling. Taste is a mix of dark fruit, molasses, plum, dark cherry into some slight oak, vanilla, whiskey notes, spicy, yeasty notes as well, finishing fairly sweet, slight booze but not over the top.

On tap @ Chucks 85th. Pours heavily murky deep ruddy caramel brown with medium thick off white head that fades quickly and laces well. Aroma is huge sticky sweet molasses, nutty roasted toffee, rum and port soaked barrels... wow. Taste is thick syrupy caramel malt with tons on barrel aged notes on the finish. Clearly boozy, but so clean it tastes well under 12%. Amazingly clean finish given all the huge flavors here. Not my favorite style, but the quality is impossible to deny - this is really good.

Wax dipped bomber. Deep copper pour with a sudsy layer of light brown foam. Aroma is a mix of molasses, Belgian yeast, dark fruits and oak. Taste blends candi sugar, fig and toffee at the start followed by notes of black cherry, clove and vanilla. Just a hint of rye whiskey and red wine in there as well. The body is moderately thick and creamy with soft carbonation and a final dose of dark sugars and toasted oak in the finish. While its closer to a Belgian Strong Dark Ale than a Quad, the barrel aging adds a nice bite to it.

Very nice, not too sweet. The pomegranate really shines through. Wood, earth, dates, brandy, candied dark fruits, mild bourbon sweetness. Needs some time in the bottle reach full potential. I like it!

Draught @ Deschutes, Portland, OR 

Pours reddish brown wirh a small head. Aroma of wood, malts, oak, vinous notes, vanilla, raisins and berries. Taste is heavy, sweet, woody and vinous with loads of oak, berries and vanills. Finish is strong, woody and malty. Quite massive and complex.
Dark plum colored pour with an off white. Barrel and vinous aromas. Big caramel malt, brown sugar, toffee, vinous, and oak notes. A bit confused in my opinion. Good body with an average mouthfeel.

22oz bottle. Reddish brown pour with lacing and legs. Lots of aromas, cotton candy, cherries, vanilla, some funk. Caramel background with bubblegum and whiskey. Flavors are sweet and smooth with lots of dark fruits, a honey sweetness, cherries, bananas. Slight tartness. Burn from the alcohol in the finish. Very complex. A little on the sweet side for me.
Pours a dark mahogany with a nice off white head. Had an aroma of alcohol and dark fruits. Taste is figgy, earthy, and grainy. This is not my type of beer. Too strong on the alcohol.

Bottle to tulip
Bubble gum, wheat, rye, and dark fruit. Mostly transparent reddish amber with a thin light tan ringed head. Dark fruit, yeast, plum, and raisins.

Bottle - Lots of brown sugar and raisin, with a nice sweetness. Clear dark brown with a thin beige head. Nice and fruity, with raisins and brown sugar, a long plum finish. Overall a bit nice, but boozy so I would let it sit a bit.

Draft. Dark ruddy brown color with a light tan head. Overripe fruit, prune, brown sugar, and bubblegum aroma. Intense flavor, a bit overwhelming. Loads of sweet dark fruit, prune and sugar plum. Boozy. Full body with lots of booze warmth. Flavorful, but I actually AM THE STOIC on this, since its pretty middling.

On tap at the Portland pub. Mahogany color with off white head. Aroma and taste of caramel and dark fruits. Taste is sweet, no bitterness. Medium mouthfeel. Sweet finish. Sweeter than many quads. Nice.

Shared bomber, poured to snifters, showing a clear mahogany hue, with a modest layer of off white head foam that reduced rather expeditiously to a ring & film, and left some spots & strands of lacing. The nose immediately introduced some lurking alcohol, then dark fruit, grape, some barrel hints & spice, and malty/ dark caramel sweetness. Ditto on the flavor, with boozy warmth, soft carbonation, just a hint of tannic tartness, and a medium+ body. A tasty sipper!
Tap. Sweet, port like, dark fruits, caramel, oak woodiness, slightly boozy. Smooth sipper.
On tap at Capones. Poured an amberish color with a small sized head. Sweet. Dark fruits, wood/oak, caramel, and some lighter spices. A bit too sweet for me, but not cloying.

Pours amber without much head or lacing. Oak integrated very well. Sweet, caramelized malt on finish with some light raisin and prune, though not super prominent. A little too syrupy for me, but still decent. Tap at Good Dog event.
Aroma is dark fruit/plums, malts and pomegranate. The flavor is dark fruit/grapes, sugar/dark sugar, fruit, malts and a mildly alcoholic/slightly sour finish.
Growler poured dark reddish brown with little head. Aroma of oak, fruit, malts. Taste is rich, sweet and fruity. A little alcohol burn at finish. Very good!

Best after April 22, 2015.

It pours a clear auburn with an off white head of foam thats about an inch thick. The foam starts to shrink and leaves some pretty lacing behind.

The nose the barrel aging goodness of oak up front with it leaning more towards the rye whisky barrel than the wine barrel. Sweet notes from the molasses are not timid and the fruitiness must be from the pomegranate; Ive never actually ate one of them. Nyuck, Nyuck. With 30% of the beer hitting the barrel, I expected some booze to show up and it does.

Ha. That fruitiness is the first thing I notice with the oak barrel aging, rye first-wine second but not by much. The sweet from the molasses comes in next and to my reckoning, does not make this brew overly sweet. The 10% abv? Yep, its there. Tolerable.

This is, to my mind, a full bodied brew with a light but right level of carbonation. Just a bit of fizz on my tongue right before the swallow.

Tossing the barrel aging aside, I think it meets the style nicely. I could have used this brew during the very brutal Winter we had. Ill buy more.

22 oz. bottle. Pours a dark reddish with a medium tan head. Sweet, fruity aroma with mild oak and barrel notes. Apparent alcohol. Flavor is bracingly sweet. Apparent booziness. Belgian candi sugar notes and fruity molasses notes. Syrupy bodied. Finishes boozy and sweet. In a style I usually like, this is not my style.
Draft. Pours deep purple with a wine like plum aroma. A little boozy. Strong tasting beer, with oak, plum and some grape. Sweet finish. Overall, this is a solid beer.
Tap at Happy Gnome. Clear amber pour with a white head. Im picking up the pomegranate - very nice. Dark fruit, good heft to the body. Slightly spicy and Im getting just a hint of wood. Really nice.

Bomber. First things first: fuck this wax shit -- unless its your anniversary beer, or your annual shut down the brewery for a day release beer, save the wax for the people at Makers Mark. Okay, got that outta the way... so, pours a deep chestnut brown, medium tannish head with okay retention and very little in the way of lacing. Nose is sweet and port-like, maple, vanilla, honey, dried fruit, tobacco, yeastiness tying it all together. Mouth is oily on the roof of the mouth, but medium bodied otherwise, lots of candy sugar, caramelly with vanilla, maple, hints of various barrels, wood, figs, dates, slight warmth in finish. Solid overall, but still a bit pricey for what it is.

On tap at Barrels & Bottles. Reddish brown appearance with a dissipating light tan head. Aroma of dark fruits, oak, caramel, light candi sugar, molasses, light chocolate, Belgian notes, light clove and a touch of spice. Similar flavor, smooth, creamy and complex. Medium sweetness and minimal bitterness. Full body. Nicely done, an excellent sipper.

25 may 2014, bottle. Amber, clear, no bubbles. Nose is grape jello and alcohol. Med/thin body and mildly fizzy. Really sugary, grape jam, alcohol. Too sweet. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From the waxed 650 ml. bottle dated 04/27/15. So I could have had this a year from now. Thanks jcwattsrugger!. Near black pour with little to no head. The aroma has a sweetness to it maybe due to the pomegranates they add to the mix. Also a sort of light black licorice note. No booze for a 12+%. Medium body with a definite bite. The taste is powerful to say the least with the dark malts, licorice, pomegranates, and modest bitterness. It drills deep into my senses at the finish but the alcohol is next to invisible.
On tap @ the Red Hot. Dark brown, thin white head. Scent is booze and caramel. Taste is sweet and a little malty. A little burn. Pretty good beer.

Hazy henna/dark amber capped by a rocky inch high head. Very aromatic elixir this be, smelling of warm raisins, cherries a fermenting, lemon rind, charred wood, dark maple syrup and toasted grainy bread. The soft and syrupy body add to the manner in which the flavours sit on your tongue and seep in. You get all of the taste the smells imply plus some winey, musty complexity, light spices and banana. Good work Deschutes! Wish I was Flemish enough to sesh this bitch.

This beer gets your attention right up front when you inhale the wonderful aroma. Once you take a sip the flavors reflect what your olfactory receptors have predicted and the mouth feel is incredible. There is very minimal tartness, thanks to the barrel aging, and the caramel smoothness is pleasant as it heads down the hatch.

10 oz. pour in a tulip glass, on tap at Republics Uptown Minneapolis location. Consumed on 5-21-14. Pours a maroon to medium brown with a bright reddish copper hue and a small amount of beige head. Looks good. Scents of plum, banana, and caramel. Orange tartness and a cool, wintry dustiness in the aroma. It was served excessively cold, thus numbing and dumbing down the aroma. Boozy bitterness in the flavor. Spicy (cinnamon, cumin). Lemon tartness. Bready (muffin, banana bread). Chocolate-covered raisin and caramel flavors. Plummy finish and aftertaste. Not the Stoic straddles the line between a subpar American imitation and an authentic Belgian taste. It ends up good but not great. Lively in the palate. Medium to full body. The palate similarly verges on that excessive, thin, hot frothiness of poor Belgian imitations but ultimately is okay. This beer would be good to pair with dinner or dessert, I suspect, but, unfortunately, I was not eating as I consumed it. It has a nice aroma and flavor but they are not strong enough. Again, it would have helped if Republic, which wants to be considered a top notch beer bar, didnt serve its beer at refrigerator temperatures. Nonetheless, it did warm up somewhat over time, and I was hoping for more powerful scents and flavors as it did so, but they never came. Oh well. Its a decent beer overall, but it left me disappointed.

Best after 22APR15

Pours a brown ale with broken and scattered light tan foam. Smells of dark cherry, wood, toasted malts, some belgian yeast and a bit of molasses. Flavor is sweet with rye, some marshmallow then an alcohol burn, some acetone and prunes. Medium on thin bodied with reserved carbonation and an off dry finish. Well, this is an interesting take, but they really need to let the yeast sing in their beer, this isnt it.
One of the best American quads Ive tried, rich and dark, some mellow alcohol warmth, elements of aged wood, dried fruit. Near perfect.

Poured from tap to tulip glass. Copper hue with off white head that dissipated to a ring. Aroma is candy like with essence of lactic, rye, sugar, esters, oak, grapes, bubblegum, earthy must, ethanol. Mouthfeel is nice with a medium body and delicate carbonation. Taste is sweet throughout with a slight medicinal ethanol finish. Overall there is a lot going on...Im not sure if its working or if I actually like it...its interesting.
A superb quad. Aromas of dark dried fruit, sweet bubblegum, some maple too. Flavors are sweet at first... Dark dried fruits, dried apple, bubblegum, a bitter woodiness to round it out. Awesome.
Tap. Pours clear ruby chestnut, tiny off white head, little lacing. Aroma is port, toffee, spices. Flavor is medium sweet, spiced, malty, vinous. Medium body, low carbonation.

Dark caramel color. Not very carbonated. Pick up some caramel and toffee on the nose, banana and clove. Wonderfully full-bodied and complex. A little boozy, the whiskey comes through. Caramel. Smooth. I love this.

Reddish brown in color.... Virtually no head... Body is cognac whiskey... Aroma of berries, tobacco , dark cherry, rye whiskey, tannins... Flavor is intensely fruity initially, lots of plum, dark fruits, berries... Caramel, toffee, gives way to tobacco, oak, spice on palate... Very complex, gets much better as it warms... Do not drink cold

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Waxed bomber from the Nugget in Woodland, CA. Pours pretty darkly ruddy copper with a slight, transient beige head. Aroma of medium dark fruit. Not exactly red berry. Maybe red berry mixed with fruit. Med + body. Flavor is oaky, a little alcohol, red berry, some rye spice, some wood. It is a bit complicated, and gets a bit sweet every once in awhile. Not exactly plummy, but close enough to make me happy. This is really, really tasty quad.

2 ounce bottle pour at SAVORs Friday night session. Pours dark brown with off-white head. Aromas of herbs, floral notes, spices, caramel. Tasting notes of sweet malt, caramel, dark fruit, spices. Medium body with a dry finish.

on tap at the pine box. rich and different. like an english barleywine barrelled on bourbon. sipper. the combo of rye(yeh) and tannic pinoit noir gand pommegrrant give it a normal bourbony finish.not so quad. will rate higher as a bw.

On draught at Deschutes Brewery & Public House, Portland, served in a stemmed snifter. Clear black cherry amber color. Aroma is raisin, prune, rye, pomegranate, and cantaloupe. Taste is candi sugar, pomegranate, rye, pinot, and dark pitted fruits. Quite sweet, but I enjoy that, and the rye whiskey barrel aging helps it from being too sweet. Prune and rye aftertaste.

On draught at deschutes Pdx - pours dark amber with small but sustaining head. Nose of booze, red wine, and tart fruit. Taste is complex blend of dark cherry, yeast, booze, cranberry, plum, and grape koolaid. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
